newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan says no policy yet but studying Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Japan says no policy yet but studying Zaire.

text.p: Japan said on Tuesday it had not yet decided to join a Canadian-led multinational force to Zaire but said an envoy had already met Zaire's leaders, a government spokesman said.

"Japan is now studying various ways in which we can contribute to resolving the crisis in Zaire, but we have not yet formed a policy," Foreign Ministry spokesman Hiroshi Hashimoto told a news conference.
He was replying to a reporter who asked if Japan was ready to send troops to Zaire to provide assistance for hundreds of thousands of refugees threatened by ethnic violence.
Sources at the United Nations said Canada offered to lead a multinational force to help end the crisis in eastern Zaire.
On Tuesday, Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien and his Japanese counterpart Ryutaro Hashimoto exchanged views on Zaire in a telephone conversation, Foreign Ministry officials said.
The two leaders, however, did not discuss the question of troops for the U.N. contingent, the officials said.
Japan is no stranger to the area. In 1994, Japan sent a group of 260 army and air force personnel to a Rwandan refugee camp in Goma, Zaire, to assist in logistics and medical support.
Special envoy Seigi Hinata, deputy director-general of the Foreign Ministry's Africa Division, met Zaire's leaders last week, ministry officials said.
The officials said Hinata conveyed Japan's hopes for a peaceful resolution of the conflict. Hinata was not asked about the possible dispatch of troops, the officials said.
Hinata returns to Tokyo on November 17 after visits to Johannesburg, Kinshasa, Dar-es-Salaam, Nairobi, Kigali, Addis Ababa and Paris.
